newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada's Marchi hopes for MMT ban vote next week.
newsitem.headline: Canada's Marchi hopes for MMT ban vote next week.

text.p: Canadian Environment Minister Sergio Marchi said on Thursday he hoped that parliament would vote next week on a bill to ban the gasoline addictive MMT.
"It's still very much a priority," said Marchi told Reuters after a news conference.
The proposed legislation, which would ban the sale and imports of the widely used octane-enhancer has reached the final debate stage in the House of Commons, the lower chamber of Canada's parliament.
Marchi said the government was determined to pass the bill. If it survived a House of Commons vote, the bill would then go to the Senate for final approval.
The proposed legislation has pitted two of Canada's most powerful lobbies against each other.
The auto industry supports the MMT ban, claiming the additive gums up auto emission diagnostic systems.
But the oil industry says the bill is a needless piece of legislation that will cost it tens of millions of dollars.

Last month, Richmond, Va.-based Ethyl Corp threatened Canada government with a US$201 million lawsuit under the North American Free Trade Agreement over the proposed MMT legislation. Ethyl's Ethyl Canada unit is the only importer and manufacturer of MMT in Canada.
Environment and health groups said that MMT, because of its key ingredient, manganese, was a potential neuro-toxin that might hurt brain development.
MMT, methylcyclopentadienyl manganese tricarbonyl, has been used as a replacement for lead in gasoline in Canada for 19 years.
In late 1995, the controversial additive was allowed for use in the United States after the U.S. Court of Appeals overruled Environmental Protection Agency objections to it.
